title: Miss Home with Kitten
credit_line: J. Willis Dalzell Memorial Collection, gift of Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell
provenance_text:
John Hoppner [1758-1810], London, England (attributed to). Sale, Christie, Manson & Woods, London, England, July 12, 1912, lot 61 [1]; purchased by Asher Wertheimer [c. 1844-1918], London, England [2]. Frank Bulkeley Smith [1864-1918], Worcester, MA until October 1918; his estate until April 1920; his estate sale, American Art Association, New York, NY, April 23, 1920, no. 103 [3]. Thomas Agnew & Sons, London, England, 1922 [4]; John Levy Galleries, New York, NY, by December 1922 [5]; Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell (Mary Beer Dalzell) [1844-1929], Pittsburgh, PA, December 1922 until June 13, 1926; her gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, June 1926.

Notes:
[1]. Sale entitled "Important Portraits of the Early British School and Pictures by Old Masters." The painting was listed as "Portrait of Miss Home, daughter of Sir Everard Home, Bart., first President of the Royal College of Surgeons" by J. Hoppner, R.A. 
[2]. Purchased for £693 (see copy of annotated auction catalogue from Frick Art Reference Library in curatorial file.) The New York Times also reported the sale price (660 guineas or $3300) in its report of the auction on July 13, 1912.
[3]. Sale entitled "Early American and British Portraits, Landscapes and Historical Pictures Formed by the Connoisseur, the Late Frank Bulkeley Smith of Worcester, Mass." The sale was held on April 22-23, 1920 at the Plaza Hotel, New York, NY. This work sold for $550 on the second evening of the sale (see copy of American Art Annual, Volume XVII, 1920, p. 303.) It was listed as "Portrait of Miss Home ("The Girl with the Kitten") by John Hoppner, R.A. 
[4]. The Agnew provenance is recorded in two sources. According to notes on the Dalzell collection by Theodore Allen Heinrich, Director, The Royal Ontario Museum, dated June 18, 1956, "Miss Home" by Hoppner was purchased “via Agnew 12.16.22” for $17,300. A 1926 listing of Mrs. Dalzell's paintings compiled by J. J. Gillespie, Pittsburgh, PA, states that this work was "Purchased through Thomas Agnew & Sons- London" but gives a price of $15,000. See also note [5] below.
[5]. John Levy Galleries # 18646. See curatorial file for duplicate invoice from John Levy Galleries to Mrs. J. W. Dalzell, dated December 16, 1922. The price is given as $17,300. The transaction involved a credit for return of two other works valued at $8,300, resulting in a net invoice amount of $9,000.
